awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Influence of Cultural Variables, Perceptions, and Earthquake Hazard Information on Household Emergency Preparedness
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the effect of cultural variables and different forms of earthquake hazard information on seismic risk perception and preparedness in the Portland (Oregon) Metropolitan Area. The potential societal impact of this work is four-fold. First, the research findings will improve university teaching by being incorporated into the investigator's course materials and textbooks. Second, the project will recruit doctoral students from demographic groups that are historically under-represented in scientific and engineering disciplines. Third, it will involve members of the Latino community, thus increasing community engagement. Finally, the collaborative relationship with local and state emergency management agencies will provide a means of disseminating improved hazard maps and other methods of communicating earthquake hazard information to the public. 

This project has three specific objectives. First, it will assess the influence of media attention concerning the Cascadia earthquake hazard on earthquake emergency preparedness by households in the surrounding area. Second, it will assess the degree to which different types of hazard maps are accessible and useful to local residents. Third, it will examine the relative effectiveness of active and passive communication strategies in promoting earthquake risk perception and household emergency preparedness. To accomplish these objectives, residents in at-risk areas study will complete a seismic risk perception and preparedness questionnaire, and will have access to information sources to inform their assessments of hazard risk. The effects of information use will be assessed and compared with those collected from individuals attending in-person training sessions  based on active-learning techniques and goal-setting strategies. The influence of cultural factors on preparedness attitudes and behavior will be assessed by working with the Portland Latino population using the same materials and approaches, provided in Spanish.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the effect of cultural variables and different forms of earthquake hazard information on seismic risk perception and preparedness in the Portland (Oregon) Metropolitan Area. Our multi-objective project used a seismic risk perception and preparedness questionnaire to assess participants’ perceptions of risk, preparedness intention, and preparedness actions. Questionnaires were distributed through a random sample mail-out survey. Participants filled out the questionnaire, then received pamphlets regarding earthquake risk and were asked to complete the questionnaire again to assess the impact of the information on risk perception and preparedness intention. We used a similar pre- and post-questionnaire strategy with active-learning based workshops. 

First, we examined whether local preparedness campaigns promoted protective knowledge and motivated hazard adjustments for residents of the Portland, Oregon metropolitan region using a random sample mail-out survey. We found that, while residents are aware that earthquakes can happen, they are less aware of the risks earthquakes pose to their homes. Further, only 37% of residents intend to “Drop, Cover, and Hold On” during an earthquake. Then, we examined the degree to which different types of hazard maps are accessible and useful to local residents. We also find that information seeking behavior has the strongest influence on preparedness, and that emergency management websites are the most trusted and understandable source of information. 

Second, we investigated if updating an interactive hazard map using best practices from the literature improves user map comprehension. We created a rubric for hazard mapping best practices, based on the literature, and used it to update the Oregon Department of Geology and Mineral Industries hazard map. Boise State University students participated in an experimental design to assess if the update map improved map comprehension. We also assessed correlations between self-reported spatial ability and map comprehension. We found that those who viewed the ‘best practices’ map did not have significantly better map comprehension scores relative to those who viewed the original map, perhaps because the existing map scores better on our map best practices rubric relative to most interactive maps. We also found that self-reported spatial ability is positively correlated with map comprehension tests. 

Third, we examined the relative effectiveness of active and passive communication strategies in promoting earthquake risk perception and household emergency preparedness. We collaboratively developed a workshop with local emergency managers with information targeted to the LatinX population, delivered in Spanish by local facilitators to 52 participants. The workshop used active learning principles to engage participants about Cascadia earthquake impacts and preparedness actions. We finished with goal setting activities to motivate participants’ preparedness. Post-workshop questionnaires showed improved risk area identification accuracy for shaking zone (but not liquefaction zone), an increase in the positive affect variables and self-efficacy and, most important, an intention to prepare relative to pre-workshop questionnaire. These results indicate that an active learning strategy that presents personalized, clear, and culturally appropriate information is a promising method of risk communication.  

With respect to societal impact, our research findings are being implemented in a range of new studies, including the recently awarded wildfire project (Award #2230618), and in our university classrooms. The project supported a female PhD student with many opportunities for professional development including the publishing of an article in The Conversation motivated by this work that was read by over 100,000 peopleOur collaborative relationship with local and state emergency management agencies provided a means of both improving hazard education and providing new strategies for local facilitators to deliver hazard information to the public. Involvement with the Latino leaders and population increased engagement and provided culturally appropriate materials to a traditionally marginalized community. We also plan to publish these materials on DesignSafe so they can be adapted for other communities and hazards.
